questions.text:
A mother who had given birth to a female child flees with her husband late at night, leaving the baby behind at the hospital. This act is punishable under which section of the IPC?

IPC: Indian penal code
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario depicts an act with the intention of abandoning a child who is under the age of 12 years, which is a punishable offense under Section 317 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC).

Section 317 of the IPC states that if the father or mother or anyone having the care of a child under the age of twelve years, leaves the child in any place with the intention of abandoning the child, they shall be punished with imprisonment up to seven years even more so for a term. The punishment may extend to ten years if the child so exposed or abandoned is a girl child. They may also be asked to pay a fine of up to 1 lakh rupees.

In India, infanticide is considered murder, and punishment is given under section 302 IPC.

Option C: IPC 316 – Causing the death of a quick unborn child (fetus whose movements can be felt) by any act amounts to culpable homicide. Punishment can be up to ten years imprisonment. If it is performed after a test confirming the gender of the fetus to be female, they may be punished with imprisonment for life and a fine of 2 lakh rupees.

Option D: IPC 315 – This section covers a person doing an act intended to prevent the child from being born alive or to cause it to die after its birth. They are punished with imprisonment for up to 7 years. If it is performed after a test confirming the gender of the fetus to be female, they may be punished with imprisonment for life and a fine of 1 lakh rupees.

Option A: Section 318 IPC – It deals with concealment of birth.

questions.text: A first-year ophthalmology resident is asked to counsel the parents of a 1-month-old infant diagnosed with a lamellar congenital cataract in both eyes. He discusses the treatment options and mentions that the following lens will be used in the surgery. This lens is a __________

choices.text: Posterior chamber intra ocular lens (modified C-loop type)
Singh and Worst's iris claw lens
Posterior chamber intra ocular lens (four loop type)

questions.solution:
Cataract surgery with an intraocular lens (IOL) implantation is the treatment of choice in congenital cataracts. The above image depicts a modified C-loop type of posterior chamber intraocular lens (PCIOL) used in such cases.

This surgery involves an extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) with primary posterior capsulorhexis and anterior vitrectomy. After removal of the cataractous lens, a posterior chamber intraocular lens (PCIOL) is implanted.

PCIOL rest entirely behind the iris. They may be supported and fixed as follows:

  • Capsular bag fixation of PCIOL (most ideal method)
  • Ciliary sulcus fixation
  • Sclera fixation

Parts of the IOL:

  • The central part overlying the optic axis is called the optic.
  • The peripheral arms used for placement and stabilization are the haptics.

 The image given below shows different types of intraocular lens.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with painful blisters on the skin and oral mucosa. Direct immunofluorescence is given below. Which of the following is false regarding the same?

choices.text: Suprabasal acantholytic blister is a characteristic feature

questions.solution:
Antibodies against hemidesmosomes is the false statement as the given image shows a characteristic fish-net appearance on direct immunofluorescence, which is diagnostic of pemphigus vulgaris. The antibodies are against the desmosomal adhesion proteins such as desmogleins 1 and 3.

This pattern is due to intraepidermal intercellular deposition of IgG and C3.

The first-line investigation in pemphigus vulgaris is the Tzanck smear. It allows us to visualize the histology by collecting material from the floor of a fresh blister that is stained with Giemsa or any Romanowsky stain. Tzanck cells are seen on microscopy.

 

Direct immunofluorescence microscopy (DIF) is the most accurate test.

Antibodies against hemidesmosomes that link basal keratinocytes to the underlying basement membrane are seen in bullous pemphigoid.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman, who recently received a kidney transplant 3 months ago, develops a high fever and severe dyspnea with a dry cough. Chest X-ray reveals diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates. Which of the following agents is most likely to have caused this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with high fever, dry cough, and bilateral interstitial infiltrates on chest radiograph after a kidney transplant is likely to be infected with Cytomegalovirus (CMV). 

CMV is a herpes virus that is the most common cause of congenital infections and the most common viral infection in solid organ transplant recipients. It is most commonly seen 1-4 months after solid organ transplantation. It can occur due to latent reactivation, donor transmission, or virus present in donor leukocytes. Many of the transplant recipients develop symptomatic CMV infection. 

The CMV virus causes cytopathic effects. Perinuclear cytoplasmic inclusions and intranuclear inclusions can form in addition to multinucleated cells. 

It usually presents within a few months after the transplant with fever, pneumonia, gastrointestinal ulcers, hepatitis, retinitis, and acute or chronic graft dysfunction. 

In immunocompromised hosts, such as those receiving solid organ transplants, chemotherapy, or immunodeficiency syndromes, the infection is more severe. It may present with infectious mononucleosis-like syndrome or can be subclinical. Pneumonia and colitis are most commonly seen. 

Congenital CMV infection may lead to developmental defects, growth retardation, jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, microcephaly, hearing loss, retinitis, and intellectual disability. 

It is treated with ganciclovir. Transplants recipients and donors may also be screened for CMV and recipients may be given prophylactic ganciclovir. 

Other options:

Option A - Adenovirus is associated with conjunctivitis and acute respiratory disease in military recruits, among other diseases.

Option C - Although influenza can cause pneumonia, there is no mention of season, and CMV is still the most common cause in transplant patients.

Option D - Respiratory syncytial virus is usually seen in children (especially premature infants).

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site involved in discoid lupus erythematosus?
questions.solution:
Discoid lupus erythematosus is a benign inflammatory disorder of the skin, most frequently involving the face and scalp. 

It is characterized by well‐defined red, scaly patches of variable size, which heal with atrophy, scarring, and pigmentary changes. The circumscribed or discoid form is the most frequent type of disease and occurs particularly on the cheeks, bridge of the nose, ears, side of the neck, and scalp.

The image below shows a localized discoid lupus erythematosus of the scalp with follicular plugging.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman comes to the primary health center for advice on contraception. She was advised to use the contraceptive provided under the Antara program. The dosage of the drug used in this contraceptive is_____.

I.M: Intramuscular
questions.solution:
The Antara program provides injectable contraceptive MPA (Medroxyprogesterone acetate). The dosage of the drug is 150 mg I.M., every 3 months. 

It acts by inhibiting ovulation, cervical mucus thickening and thereby preventing sperm penetration, and endometrial atrophy preventing implantation.

The first dose can be taken anytime after regular menstruation or after 6 weeks of delivery or immediately after abortion. Injectable contraceptives can be given up to 2 weeks prior to the due date to up to 4 weeks after the post-due date.

This injectable contraceptive should not be given to a woman with:

  • Unexplained vaginal bleeding 
  • Stroke or severe diabetes
  • Breast cancer (past/present)
  • Active hepatitis or liver tumor
  • A desire for a rapid return to fertility.

Disadvantages are:

  • Menstrual irregularities: Light/heavy bleeding/amenorrhoea
  • Slight weight gain
  • No protection against HIV/sexually transmitted diseases (STDs)
  • A slight loss in bone mineral density during the first 2 years of use.

This injectable contraceptive is not to be refrigerated. It is to be stored always at room temperature (15-30oC).

Antara [Injectable contraceptive depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA)] and Chhaya (oral contraceptive Centchroman) were launched by the Government of India under its Mission Parivar Vikas. 

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: A 40-year-old chronic alcoholic presents with confusion, memory loss, and agitation. On examination, he is disoriented and horizontal nystagmus is noted. Which of the following enzyme markers can aid the diagnosis of the patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
The features of confusion, memory loss, and horizontal nystagmus in a chronic alcoholic are suggestive of Wernicke's encephalopathy caused due to deficiency of thiamine (Vitamin B1). This can be diagnosed by erythrocyte transketolase assay.

Thiamine (Vitamin B1) is a water-soluble vitamin, required for carbohydrate metabolism. Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) is its coenzyme form and is required for the following enzymes:

  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase 
  • Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase in citric acid cycle
  • Branched-chain keto acid dehydrogenase in the metabolism of leucine, isoleucine, and valine
  • Transketolase

Thiamine deficiency leads to the following:

Beriberi - anorexia, dyspepsia, heaviness, peripheral neuropathy, and weakness (dry beriberi) or with cardiovascular features like edema, palpitations, breathlessness, distended neck veins (wet beriberi)

Wernicke’s encephalopathy is associated with chronic alcohol abuse which lead to thiamine deficiency because of poor nutritional habits, or malabsorption. It is an acute neurological disorder characterized by:

  • Global confusion
  • Ocular abnormalities like horizontal nystagmus, gaze palsy, anisocoria, and sluggish pupillary reflex
  • Ataxia - mainly affecting the gait
  • Vestibular dysfunction

Korsakoff's syndrome is a neuropsychiatric disorder characterized by confabulation and memory defects. Immediate memory is generally maintained but short-term memory is diminished.

The initial treatment in a patient with Wernicke's disease should be emergent thiamine infusion, either IM or IV. This should be given daily until a normal diet is resumed and before treatment with IV glucose. Administration of glucose before thiamine can worsen Wernicke's encephalopathy.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with complaints of nasal blockage and bleeding from the nose. On evaluation, he was diagnosed with a nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. Which of the following is true regarding the disease?

choices.text: Blood supply is from the internal maxillary artery
Biopsy is the investigation of choice
Arises from the medial wall of the nasal cavity

questions.solution:
The blood supply of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is most commonly from the ipsilateral internal maxillary artery. 

Angiofibroma is the most common benign tumor of the nasopharynx, commonly affecting young males. It originates from the fibrovascular stroma on the posterolateral wall of the nasal cavity close to the area of the sphenopalatine foramen and the pterygoid base.

It is a histologically benign but locally aggressive tumor that grows at the back of the nasal cavity. Blood supply is most commonly from the ipsilateral internal maxillary artery or sphenopalatine artery. It encroaches by expanding into surrounding areas like the nasal cavity, sphenoidal sinus, pterygopalatine fossa, maxillary sinus, orbit, and cranial cavity.

Clinical features include:

  • Difficulty breathing through the nose
  • Epistaxis
  • Rhinolalia clausa (hyponasal speech)
  • Bulging of the soft palate 
  • Underdeveloped secondary sexual characters

Tumour diagnosis is based on the characteristic findings on CT, MRI, and angiography. Biopsy should not be undertaken as it is a highly vascular tumour and can lead to severe bleeding.

Endoscopic resection is preferred in tumours that are limited to nasal cavity, nasopharynx, sphenoid sinus and pterygopalatine fossa. Further extensions are managed with excision of the tumor by: 

  • Wilson’s trans-palatal approach
  • Lateral rhinotomy

Radiation can be used in cases of intracranial extension.

questions.text: A 2-year-old baby weighing 15 kg was brought to the hospital with a history of loose stools. He is afebrile, and there is no blood in his stools. The baby is lethargic. On examination, the eyes are sunken and during the skin pinch test, the skin retraction took more than two seconds. On offering water the child does not show eagerness to drink and responds poorly. Which of the following is correct concerning the treatment of dehydration in this child?

choices.text: 600 ml to be given as IV in the first 1 hour
600 ml to be given as IV in the first  half hour
450 ml to be given as IV in the first half hour
450 ml to be given as IV in the first 1 hour

questions.solution:
The child in this scenario has severe dehydration, as indicated by lethargy, and sunken eyes, and the skin goes back slowly on the skin pinch test (>2 seconds). 450 ml to be given as IV in the first half hour is correct for the treatment of dehydration in this child.

Severe dehydration requires treatment plan C. This involves using intravenous fluids (ringer lactate with 5% dextrose).

100ml/kg of fluid should be given over 3 hours in children aged more than 12 months. For those who are less than 12 months old, the fluid should be given over 6 hours.

The fluid requirement for severe dehydration is as follows:

Age 30 mL/kg 70 mL/kg
<12 months 1 hr 5 hr
>12 months 30 min 2.5 hr

Calculation of fluid required: The baby requires 30 mL/kg fluid and the weight of the baby is 15 kg. 

Therefore, the total fluid requirement is: 

15 kg x 30 mL/kg = 450 ml fluids in the first half-hour, and

15 kg x 70 mL/kg = 1050 ml over the next 2.5 hours.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient came with complaints of episodes of shortness of breath and coughing at night, which awakens him from sleep. On examination, distended neck veins were observed, and S3 was heard on auscultation. Which of the following biomarkers is routinely used for the diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of dyspnea, orthopnea, distended neck veins, and S3 suggests a diagnosis of heart failure and brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) can be used to confirm this.

Natriuretic peptides are protein molecules that are secreted by the ventricular myocytes in response to myocardial stretch or stress.

Ventricular musculature releases pre-proBNP, which is cleaved into BNP and NT-proBNP (N-terminal proBNP). They cause natriuresis, vasodilatation, and diuresis, which leads to improved myocardial relaxation.  These peptides also counteract the actions of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. 

Measurement of both BNP and inert NT-proBNP levels can be used in the diagnosis of heart failure and to determine the prognosis.

Newer markers like soluble ST-2 and galectin-3 can be used to determine the prognosis of heart failure.

Other options: 

Option B - Apolipoprotein C3 is a biomarker for Alzheimer's disease. 

Option C - Endothelin-1 (ET-1) can be used in the diagnosis and prognosis of heart failure, but it is not routinely used. 

Option D - Adrenomedullin is increased in heart failure and has prognostic significance.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman who was recently diagnosed with placenta increta comes to the clinic to discuss management options. She has an obstetric score of G2P1 and a previous history of C-section. Which of the following is associated with a favourable pregnancy outcome?

choices.text: Use of methotrexate post delivery to enhance placental autolysis

questions.solution:
Cesarean hysterectomy is indicated in cases of morbidly adherent placenta/placenta accreta spectrum. 

The placenta accreta spectrum is characterized by abnormally implanted, invasive, or adhered placenta. This occurs due to partial or complete absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the Nitabuch layer. Risk factors include associated placenta previa and previous cesarean delivery as seen in this patient. 

There are three variants of this condition based on the depth of trophoblastic growth.

  • Placenta accreta, the villi are attached to the myometrium.
  • Placenta increta, the villi invade into the myometrium.
  • Placenta percreta, the villi penetrate the myometrium into the serosa.

It can be diagnosed in the antepartum period by ultrasound which will reveal loss of normal hypoechoic retroplacental zone between the placenta and uterus, placental vascular lacunae, bridging vessels, and placental bulging leading to distortion of the contour of the uterus. MRI can be performed when the ultrasound is inconclusive. However, ultrasound remains the modality of choice for diagnosis.

Management of this condition involves the following

  • Appropriate surgical, anesthesia, intensive care, and blood banking capabilities
  • Recommended scheduled delivery between 34 0/7 to 35 6/7 weeks (American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists)
  • Cesarean hysterectomy to reduce risk of maternal bleeding with placenta left in situ after delivery
  • Manual removal of the placenta should not be attempted due to the increased risk of blood loss.
  • Evidence regarding use of methotrexate in resorption of placenta is lacking.

questions.text: Somatomedin mediates which of the following?

choices.text: Decreased rate of glucose uptake by cells

questions.solution:
Somatomedin refers to insulin-like growth factor 1(IGF-1) and IGF-2. It is primarily responsible for indirect actions of growth hormone. It mediates deposition of chondroitin sulfate and also stimulates collagen formation.

Growth hormone, also known as somatotropin is produced by the somatotropic cells of the anterior pituitary gland. It is released in response to growth hormone-releasing hormone which is produced by the hypothalamus. The levels of growth hormone vary throughout life. Adolescents, children, and adults have decreasing levels respectively. It has a diurnal variation, being low during the day, and increases in a pulsatile fashion at night during sleep. 

The growth hormone receptor is part of the cytokine receptor superfamily. It functions via activation of the JAK2-STAT pathway leading to binding to cytoplasmic transcription factors.  

Direct effects of growth hormone:

  • Sodium retention
  • Decreased insulin sensitivity
  • Lipolysis
  • Protein synthesis
  • Epiphyseal growth

IGF-1 mediated indirect effects:

  • Insulin-like activity
  • Anti-lipolytic activity
  • Protein synthesis
  • Epiphyseal growth

Related Pearl: Direct and Indirect (mediated via IGF-1) effects of Growth Hormone

Indirect effects of growth hormone are mediated via IGF-I. 

Direct effects of GH are shown below.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with difficulty in swallowing both solids and liquids. A barium swallow revealed the following finding. What is the best confirmatory test of the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the barium swallow showing bird beak appearance is suggestive of achalasia cardia. Manometry is done to confirm the diagnosis.

Achalasia is a primary esophageal motility disorder. It is characterized by the absence of esophageal peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) in response to swallowing. These abnormalities cause a functional obstruction at the gastroesophageal junction. 

Esophageal manometry shows:

  • Incomplete LES relaxation in response to swallowing
  • High resting LES pressure
  • Absent esophageal peristalsis

On performing a barium swallow, barium will be retained for more than five minutes. The fluoroscopic examination will reveal a dilated esophagus that tapers to form a 'bird's beak' at the gastroesophageal junction as seen in the image above. 

Endoscopy and biopsy is usually carried out to rule out cancer. 

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • Regurgitation
  • Chest pain
  • Weight loss
  • Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: A patient posted for surgery suddenly develops shortness of breath, swelling of lips and tongue, and facial swelling in the operation theatre. She was diagnosed with anaphylaxis and was immediately administered adrenaline. Which of the following is the most common cause of anaphylaxis in the peri-operative setting?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of anaphylactic reactions during anesthesia is antibiotics (especially penicillin and cephalosporin).

A careful pre-operative assessment should be conducted to rule out prior allergic events in order to avoid precipitating factors. There should be careful documentation of the history of allergies and adverse drug reactions. 

A distinction should be made between a true anaphylactic reaction and adverse side effects. Past perioperative difficulties may also be reported as drug allergies by the patients. 

Other options: 

Option A - In the perioperative period, opioids are likely to cause nausea. This is an adverse drug reaction. 

Option B - Succinylcholine can lead to conditions like hyperkalemia, masseter spasm, and malignant hyperthermia. If administered to a patient with pseudocholinesterase deficiency, they might experience prolonged neuromuscular blockade.  

Option D - Sulfa drugs like sulfonamide antibiotics, furosemide, hydrochlorothiazide, and captopril also exhibit allergy in surgical patients.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient presented with sudden onset vertigo. The episodes are accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and tinnitus but he does not notice any association with change in position. Sometimes, his ear feels full. He has progressive hearing loss. Otoscopy findings are normal. What is true about the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Bilateral conductive hearing loss is a common feature
Can be treated with Epley's manoeuvre
Occurs due to distension of the endolymphatic system

questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Meniere's disease which occurs due to the distension of the endolymphatic system.

This patient has episodic vertigo associated with aural fullness and hearing loss. These symptoms are consistent with Meniere's disease. 

Meniere's disease occurs due to increased production or decreased drainage of endolymph leading to increased volume and distension of the endolymphatic system.

It usually affects men between the ages of 35 to 60 years. Clinical features include episodic vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and fullness of the ear. Both ears can be involved, but it is generally a unilateral disease. 

The symptom of vertigo is associated with rotation of the environment or the individual themselves. The symptoms come in clusters with remission periods lasting weeks to years. The patient will be normal between episodes. Nystagmus may also be seen during acute attacks.

Rinne's test is positive and Weber's test shows lateralization to the better ear, suggestive of sensorineural hearing loss.

Pure tone audiometry (PTA) will reveal sensorineural hearing loss. Initially, the lower frequencies are affected resulting in a 'rising' curve. Later in disease progression, higher frequencies are affected leading to a 'flat' or 'falling' curve. 

Special audiometry tests will help confirm that the pathology is in the cochlea and differentiate from retrocochlear lesions. The recruitment test will be positive, the short increment sensitivity test (SISI) will be better than 70% in two-thirds of the patients (normal is 15%), and the tone decay test will be abnormal (normally less than 20 dB decay). 

Electrocochleography will show the summating potential to action potential ratio of more than 30% (normally, it is 30%).

The below image shows PTA depicting the rising curve seen in the early stages of Meniere's disease:

 

Acute attacks can be treated with bed rest and vestibular sedatives like dimenhydrinate, promethazine theoclate, or prochlorperazine. Chronic management involves vasodilators (betahistine) and diuretics. Treatment of Meniere's disease includes reassurance, smoking cessation, dietary salt not exceeding 1.5-2.0 g/day, and avoiding excessive water, coffee, tea, and alcohol intake. 

Repeated intratympanic injection of gentamicin can help most patients. 

Other surgical procedures can be done when medical treatment is unsuccessful. These include decompression of the endolymphatic sac, endolymphatic shunt operation, sacculotomy (Fick's operation), labyrinthectomy, and intermittent low-pressure pulse therapy. 

Other options: 

Epley's maneuver is used to treat benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), which is characterized by vertigo when the patient places their head in a triggering position. There is no associated hearing loss in this condition.

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:

 

Disease Findings in PTA audiogram
Conductive hearing loss AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present

questions.text: Which of the following cells secrete surfactant in lungs?
questions.solution:
Type 2 pneumocytes secrete surfactant in the lungs.

Alveolar Lining Epithelial Cells

Two types

  • Type I cells – The primary lining cells of the alveoli (squamous epithelium); Helps in gas exchange
  • Type II cells  – Granular pneumocytes produce surfactant

Type II cells make 60% of epithelial cells in alveoli but type I cells form 95% of the total surface area because of its flat surface.

Type II cells are stem cells which help in replenishing damaged Type 1 pneumocytes in conditions like drug-induced pulmonary toxicity by amiodarone, bleomycin etc. 

Other cells – Pulmonary alveolar macrophages (PAMs/type 3 alveolar cells), lymphocytes, plasma cells, neuroendocrine cells (APUD cells-Amine precursor uptake and decarboxylation), and mast cells.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included under stages of grief?
questions.solution:
Betrayal is not included in the stages of grief.

The five stages of grief are denial, anger, bargaining, depression, and acceptance. But, not all stages manifest in the same order in all patients and can also be applied to loss in other contexts such as the loss of a loved one.

Related Pearl: The 5 stages of grief model by Kübler-Ross

  • Denial - Patients may become numb and dazed at the news of their own imminent death and refuse to accept the diagnosis. 
  • Anger - Patients may get angry towards God or themselves. 
  • Bargaining - Patients may start to bargain with God or friends and doctors for a cure to buy some more time.
  • Depression - Patients may go into depression.
  • Acceptance - Patients finally accept that their death is inevitable and make further preparations (eg., making a will, etc).

questions.text:
Match the following marked structures to the correct areas of the lymph node.

       A. Germinal centre

       B. Lymphoid nodule

       C. Trabeculae

       D. Subcapsular sinus

       E. Capsule
questions.solution:
The structures marked in the above histological section of the lymph node are as follows:

1 - Capsule

2 - Subcapsular sinus

3 - Germinal centre

4 - Lymphoid nodule

5 - Trabeculae

Each lymph node consists of a connective tissue framework and of numerous lymphocytes of all types which are arranged in a stroma of reticulin fibers and cells. They form 3 major regions within each lymph node:

  1. Cortex - It contains subcapsular sinuses, lymphoid nodules, and densely packed lymphocytes. It stains darkly. Each nodule has a lightly stained germinal center surrounded by a zone of densely packed lymphocytes. 
  2. Paracortex - It lacks nodules and has fewer lymphocytes. It is, therefore, lightly stained.
  3. Medulla -  with prominent draining sinusoids adjacent to the hilum.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the condition shown in the image given below?

choices.text: Increased incidence in patients with liver cirrhosis

questions.solution:
The condition shown above is Dupuytren's contracture. The distal interphalangeal joints (DIP) are not involved. The metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints are involved. 

Dupuytren's contracture is proliferating fibroplasia involving palmar aponeurosis. It causes flexion deformity of one or more fingers as a result of abnormal thickening and shortening of the palmar aponeurosis.

It is more common in males and incidence is higher in patients with cirrhosis of the liver, diabetes, smoking, AIDS. It is also associated with vibration exposure to the wrist and hand. The ring finger is the most commonly affected. The contractures are usually limited to the medial 3 fingers. Sometimes it may be associated with the thickening of the plantar fascia (Ledderhose’s disease) and penile fascia (Peyronie's disease). 

If the deformity is mild, no treatment is required. However, surgery is indicated in cases of significant deformity. 

Surgical options for treatment of Dupuytren's contracture include needle aponeurotomy and subtotal palmar aponeurectomy, and skin grafting is considered in severe or recurrent disease.

questions.text: A middle-aged man came to the casualty with complaints of abdominal pain. On examination, it is noted that the pain radiates from the loin to the groin of the patient. The resident wants to administer a drug to the patient for symptomatic relief. Which drug is not effective in this condition?
questions.solution:
Abdominal pain radiating from loin to groin is suggestive of renal colic. Nitrates are not effective in renal colic. 

In renal colic, NSAIDs, and morphine are used for acute pain relief. Due to the short time of action of nitrates, their clinical efficacy as relaxants in genitourinary system is quite low.

Therapeutic Uses of nitrates are:

  • Angina pectoris
  • Acute coronary syndrome
  • Myocardial infarction
  • CHF
  • Biliary colic
  • Esophageal spasm
